elements.text: PART ONE
SCENE 1. INT. SPACE STATION MANDELA — OBSERVATION MODULE — 2071
(F/X VERY MODERN, VERY 2001-CLEAN ENVIRONMENT. DOCTOR AND
FLIP’S VOICES APPROACHING, MUFFLED BEHIND A BULKHEAD DOOR)
(OFF) Tranquillity, you said! Tranquillity! Not some old space station!
(OFF) This is far from “some old” space station, Miss Jackson.—
F/X BULKHEAD SLIDES OPEN, LETTING THEM IN
Yes, this must be the observation module. Come on.
F/X BULKHEAD CLOSES BEHIND AS THEY WALK TO LARGE VIEWING PORT
Oh, right. So which planet are we observing, exactly? Doesn’t look like much.
Look again, Flip. The large continent, directly below. Doesn’t it seem familiar at all?
No, why — ohh yeah, that’s India, isn’t it? Upside-down India! Hang about, that’s not some weird upside-down Earth, is it?
This isn’t a picture in an atlas, Flip. We’re in orbit, so...
. we're the ones upside-down. Alright, I get it. Where are we, then? Is this the International Space Station?
It’s the Mandela. Properly known as the Nelson Mandela International Space Station.
He must be chuffed. Is this the future, then?
Just a little way ahead of your time, yes. (RE VIEW) Look there now, there’s Bangalore. Just coming into view.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 3
(BORED) Yeah, well, I’m sure it’s very nice.
Flip! In your time, only a very few individuals have been privileged enough to take in such an extraordinary view of the entirety of the globe!
Yeah, and there it is. Out there. Where’s next?
(DURING THE NEXT LINE: F/X: BULKHEAD DOOR SLIDES OPEN. JYOTI CUTLER ENTERS. SHE’S CARRYING EQUIPMENT. )
Look at those lights. Panjim. Goa. I’ve been meaning to go to the fruit [festival.]
(ENTERING) I’ve seen it. It’s not all that.
F/X THE HEAVY DOOR SWISH-SNAPS SHUT. AND LOCKS.
(TUGGING DOCTOR'S SLEEVE) Doctor. Astronaut person?
(APPROACHING) Who are you? I thought we didn’t have any tourists on board.
I’m the Doctor, this is Flip. Can I help you with that camera, at all? (HELPS JYOTT)
(TO DOCTOR) Well, thanks. But it’s my kit, you’re not using it.
No intention.
Pretend we’re not even here.
Okay. — Only, you are supposed to be, right?
Oh, definitely.
Always.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 4
They never tell me anything. Hi — Jyoti Cutler, payload specialist. Let me at the window, I’ve got to get all this set up in time.
We’1ll be quiet. Won’t we, Doctor?
JYOTI SETTING UP CAMERA KIT.
Ah, um, I think —
Yes?
It’s just that your camera has a rather long lens and your monopod won’t keep it steady enough. And the flash isn’t going to be a lot of help, is it?
Here. If you know so much, feel free. I’ve got about seven minutes to get a camera focused on grids 32 to 17. Knock yourself out.
My pleasure. (HE SNAP-CONNECTS THE KIT TOGETHER THROUGH: )
They said I could make my film, you’d think they’d give me the time to do it. (TO FLIP) So is this Doctor the sort who needs flattery, or can I leave him to it?
I just let him talk.
I am still here, you know.
You’re brilliant, I don’t know what I’d have done without you.
What’s happening in seven minutes on grid whatever it is?
Something called “Clean Up Space 2071”.
How do you know that?
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 5
There’s a TV monitor behind you showing a news channel.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 6
SCENE 2: TV NEWS BULLETIN
A VIDEO KIND OF HUM.
[TV REPORTER] :
[Melissa] Fletcher, Newshub Nine, taking to Jessica Allaway, who’s been brought in as a sort of troubleshooter to fix the Clean Up Space project —
Never fear, the British are here.
[TV REPORTER]: People at home and here in India are questioning how qualified you are. Isn’t it true you’re simply a figurehead?
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 7
SCENE 3: INT. MANDELA OBSERVATION MODULE
I know that woman, don’t I?
Well, do you?
Yes, it’s her! Jessica... thingy. Nine-seven in the fourth, of course!
Allaway. Jessica Allaway.
Well, I’m none the wiser.
Jessica Allaway, that’s it. She won Wimbledon in 2057. It was a great final, as I recall. She beat Roger Borg.
Well, she’s not playing tennis now.
Unmute control is on the side, if you want to hear.
Thank you, yes.
F/X OVER TV MONITOR:
(D) .. Beating Roger in the fourth — that’d be a challenge
enough for most people, [but not for me. ]
F/X CROSS TO:
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 8
SCENE 4: TV NEWS BULLETIN [CONTINUOUS]
SAME VIDEO-LIKE HUM
. but not for me.
[TV REPORTER] : But surely Clean Up Space is a challenge too far for a cultural ambassador?
Clean Up Space isn’t about me, Melissa. Clean Up Space is about Britain leading the way once more.
[TV REPORTER] : Providing financial support to the Indian Space Research Agency.
(PUT OUT) Advising our overseas partners, exactly.
F/X CROSS TO:
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 9
SCENE 5. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL — DAY
(ISRA IS THE INDIAN SPACE RESEARCH AGENCY. JESSICA’S NEWS
IS ON THE BIG MONITOR. )
[TV REPORTER]: (D) So what are you doing about the cost overruns, exactly?
(D) All in good time. Now — this is launch day. If you’1l excuse me, Ms Fletcher, I’ve a job to do here. [And it’s time I got down to doing it.]
For the love of — (ALOUD) Somebody switch that woman off!
TECH #1: Got it.
THE TV IS SWITCHED OFF

Thank you! That’s how you restore Anglo-Indian relations. Wait, are the radio people recording this? Remember, I want approval. (TO EVERYONE) Right, everyone, all departments, switch headsets to circuit 1. Are we on?
TECH #2: Salim, radio wants you to say your name for the recording.

(TO TECH #2) Fair enough. (TO EVERYONE) Indian Space Centre, all departments, I’m Mission Controller Salim Jahangir. And we are getting back to the real job while Britain’s ambassador poses on the telly.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 10
SCENE 6. INT. MANDELA — OBSERVATION MODULE
[TV REPORTER]:

(D, ON MONITOR) And with questions about the spiralling cost of this project refusing to go away, we’re going back to the newsroom, for live coverage of the launch. Melissa Fletcher, Newshub Nine, [at the]
F/X JYOTI SWITCHES MONITOR OFF
Hey, we were watching that!
Sorry, causes interference. With the camera-?
Flip — we don’t want to be watching the gogglebox, when we can witness the day’s events at first hand!
This Clean Up Space thing?
It’s an historic day. I just wish Donald could see it with us.
Yeah, I’m not on first-name terms with everyone who’s anyone in the universe, you know.
He means Donald Kessler.
Indeed. He predicted this day would come, decades ago.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 11
SCENE 7. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL — DAY
(INTO HEADSET) Nav-con, status check?
VOICE 1: (OVER SPEAKER) Nav-con, go.
Flight?
TECH #2: Flight, go.
Crosswind could be better. (BEAT) But I’m calling it. Launch.
CROSS TO:
SCENE 8. EXT. ISRA — ROCKET PAD — DAY
(F/X THE BOOM AND EXPLOSIVE LAUNCH OF A SATURN-V-LIKE ROCKET.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 12
SCENE 9. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL — DAY
F/X LAUNCH CONTINUES OVER B/G MONITORS
(ALOUD, TO MISSION CONTROL) Salvage 2 launched seventeen hundred hours, two minutes, Indian Time. It’s Thursday the
twenty-eighth of May, 2071 and, ladies and gentlemen, Clean Up Space has finally begun!
F/X WHOOPS AND CHEERS FROM ASSEMBLED TECHNICIANS
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 13
SCENE 10. INT. MANDELA — OBSERVATION MODULE
Why’s there a “Clean Up Space” thing anyway? What’s there to clean up? I mean, it’s space. We’re not talking alien poop on pavements.
It’s for all the space junk.
You mean like Star Wars?

Look down there, Flip. The whole world. Bursting with life and energy and potential. Just India there, India alone has more variety and vitality than some entire planets I’ve been to. Humanity is exciting, it’s the only word for it. And yet —
‘Some entire planets’ you’ve [been to?]
He just talks like that, it’s okay.
- for all that humanity is vibrant, exciting and, yes, indomitable, you really are the most terrible litterbugs.
(F/X THE DOCTOR STANDS AND CROSSES TO THE WINDOW. RAPS ON THE GLASS)
Six inches of glass in this window. But just a single football- Sized piece of debris, flying at orbital speeds, would punch through it like it was tissue paper.
Who kicks footballs into space? Frank Lampard?
There’s just so much stuff out there.
Even in your time, Flip, NASA was tracking tens of thousands of pieces of debris. Dead satellites. Rocket engine fragments. Nuclear reactors.
They call them ‘zombie satellites’.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 14
SCENE 11. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
(BUSIER. EVERYBODY WORKING. COMPUTERS REPORTING STATUS UPDATES WITH BLEEPS. )
TECH #2: Second-sep engines reporting 30 seconds from Burn 1.
(INTO HEADSET) Nav-con, confirm Salvage 2’s automated flight program. Has it corrected for that launch crosswind?
TECH #1: (OVER SPEAKER) Corrections confirmed. Salvage 2 on course.

(INTO HEADSET) Thank you, Nav-con. (TO ALL) Ladies and gentlemen, our target is the Envisat satellite, the ironically- named “Environmental Satellite”. Decommissioned 2012, it’s a zombie satellite with a mass of 8 point 2 tonnes and we’ve had enough of it. Envisat is now designated target Alpha-Alpha-1 in our database. Salvage 2 is going to swallow that dead weight whole and chuck it into a re-entry burnup and it’s going to do it today. Let’s get that junk out of my sky.
F/X ALARMS START TO RING. ALARMED CHATTER FROM TECHNICIANS.
TECHS #1 + #2: What’s happening?
What’s gone wrong? Where’s that alarm?
(INTO HEADSET) Calm it, everyone, stand by. I’m getting power warnings. (CALLING) Ops, kill those alarms, I can’t hear. (INTO HEADSET) Flight, speak to me.
F/X ALL ALARMS STOP INSTANTLY. ALL COMPUTERS ETC STOP.
TECHS #1 + #2: I’ve lost screens.
No contact.
Radio out, power out.
INTO HEADSET) Ops? (BEAT) Nav-Con, do you hear me? (CALLING
Someone! Anyone! I need power!
F/X DOORS OFF. ENTER JESSICA
(SLIGHTLY OFF, LOUD) Never fear. The British are here.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 15
SCENE 12. INT. MANDELA — OBSERVATION MODULE
Odd. There should’ve been another burn by now.
You can spot a trajectory at this distance?
It’s a very distinctive trajectory.
There! Did you see it? Another flash. I can’t see the ship but there was a flash. Is that the burn?
Not the one I wanted to see.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 16
SCENE 13. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
Power? Anyone? Do we have anything?
(F/X SUDDENLY, POWER LURCHES BACK ON — AND AS SOON AS THE
IS BACK, THE ALARMS START BELLOWING AGAIN)
(SHOUTS) For heaven’s sake, who put the alarms on the primary circuits?
(SHOUTS) Ops! Kill the alarms!
F/X ALARMS STOP
(CALLING) You on electrical! Yes, you! Tell me why should I let you keep your job?
Quiet, please! (IGNORES HER, CALLS) Flight, it’s Salim. I’m taking over Salvage 2 from here.
Oh, no no no. I don’t think so.
TECH #2: You have control, Salim.
I have control. Jessica Allaway. I’m senior management now.
(ALOUD) Will someone please remove this ‘manager’ from my mission control!
This mess is yours? Then tell me why that rocket’s course is so off.
(WORKING COMPUTERS) It’s not, it’s — (REALISES) it is. Orbital altitude... That’s far too high. I’m going to spin it. (CALLS) Flight, I’m doing a three-second burst in three... two... firing.
F/X NEW BLEEPS INDICATE A ROCKET-ENGINE BURN IS UNDERWAY.
One... two... burn complete.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 17
BEAT... BUT THEN F/X THE BURN BLEEPS CONTINUE.
Then what’s that?
It’s another burn! Flight! Did you signal a second burn?
TECH #2: Not us.
Sort out the blame later. Salvage 2’s just looped past Alpha- Alpha-One.
(INTO HEADSET) Nav-Con, put course projections on the main screen. I want to see where it’s going.
BEAT
Nav-Con, Jessica Allaway. Put the orbital map there too. I want to see what it’s going to hit.
TECH #1: Who are you?
Nav-Con, if I have to fire everybody this minute, it’1ll just save me doing it tomorrow. Orbital map. Screen. Now.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 18
SCENE 14. INT. MANDELA — OBSERVATION ROOM
(THE DOCTOR IS ON HIS FEET, PACING. VERY AWARE THAT SOMETHING
GONE WRONG. )
Look! Another flash! But it’s so close! Why can’t I see the ship?
You can’t see it because it’s facing us head on. It’s flying straight at us. Jyoti. Go. Get everybody into the secure area, right now.
I haven’t got the authority and I’m betting you haven’t either.
It doesn’t matter who has authority. Everyone is in danger, get them to the best-protected module on the station. You have minutes. At best.
The Mandela’s a mile wide, how I can reach everybody?
Phone them?
Good idea! — well done, Flip. Now, the TARDIS.
We’re not really going to be hit, are we?
Doctor, we're not really going to run away?
No, we're going to intercept Salvage 2 in the TARDIS.
No. You intercept that thing, I'll help here. (TO JYOTI) Jyoti, show me to the phone system. Can you do that?
I don’t know if I should.
If I get this right, Flip, you might even be safer here.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 19
Oh, now, you know me. Caution is my middle name. And hey! You're always telling me not to run off. Well, here I am, not running off.
I’1l be back before you know it. And then I’m going to show you India.
No hurry.
DOCTOR EXITS.
There’s a comms panel here.
You’re up, then. Get calling.
(PRESSES A BUTTON) Attention, everyone!
(HER VOICE ECHOES OVER MAIN SPEAKERS THROUGHOUT THE STATION,
THIS MODULE)
This is an emergency! The Salvage 2 craft is on a collision course with the Mandela! All crew, evacuate to module S-Eleven immediately!
BEAT
How will we know if it’s worked?
(OVER SPEAKER) Jyoti, what are you talking about?
(INTO COMMS) Commander Gabbard. Sir! I’m serious!
(OVER SPEAKER) Then you’re imagining things.
Let me. (INTO COMMS) Hello. I’m Philippa Jackson, I’ma stowaway and she’s not imagining me, is she?
(OVER SPEAKER) You’re a what?!
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 20
You heard, deal with it. Listen: this Salvage 2 thing is coming to eat us for dinner, so get with the programme and evacuate everyone to the safe areas right now. Okay? Me out.
Wow.
I’ve got a younger brother. You learn how to get things done.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 21
SCENE 15. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
MORE BLEEPS, MORE COMPUTERS.
There’s your problem, right there. Flight computer course program has been patched. Sabotage, clear as day.
Can’t be.
Timestamps don’t lie. You’ve got yourself a saboteur.
Two saboteurs. The power short, remember?
Two separate acts of sabotage, here in mission control? That’s... unlucky.
We cannot discuss it now. (F/X BLEEPS) Look, we are running out of propellant on Salvage 2, I need to spin her into a longer, lower course.
I can do this.
My ship. My fault. I’m putting it right.
TECH #2: Time to Mandela, two minutes.
Okay. But do it faster.
F/X ALARMS START AGAIN
Are we losing power again?
It’s the Clean Up programming kicking back in. Salvage 2’s locked on a target. Commencing clean up procedure.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 22
SCENE 16. INT. MANDELA — OBSERVATION MODULE
(EVACUATION ALARMS ARE SOUNDING BUT FLIP AND JYOTI ARE IGNORING THEM. )
Okay, if we can’t get to this secure module in time, is there someone else? Somewhere without a great big window?
There it is! Look at that. Where’s my camera?
That is one ugly spaceship.
It’s opening up.
It can’t swallow the station, can it?
No chance.
That’s something.
But it can take a big bite out of our module. Got it. Filming. This is fan — LOOK! What’s that?
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 23
SCENE 17. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
Is that one of ours?
There’s something in the way. Something’s just appeared on the screen. It’s — it looks like a box.
A little box. What is that?
It’s flying into the ship. How is it flying into the ship? What aS: DE?
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 24
SCENE 18. INT. MANDELA — OBSERVATION MODULE
It’s the TARDIS. Flying in between us and that ship. I can’t
watch.
This is fantastic footage. (SEES THE TARDIS ENTERING SALVAGE 2)
Whoa!
Hang about — where’d it go? The TARDIS?
Right inside Salvage 2.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 25
SCENE 19. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
(READING) Target acquired. It thinks this, this box is the satellite it was after.
Well, whatever it is, give it a round of applause. Salvage 2’s programming will change course now. It’1ll dive straight into a steep re-entry and spit it out. The Mandela’s safe.
That was the plan, yes.
I know. I approved the procedure. How long ‘til it’s supposed to change course?
I’d say ten, maybe twenty seconds ago.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 26
SCENE 20. INT. MANDELA — OBSERVATION MODULE
Look, I’m sorry for your friend but he’s saved the station.
Look again.
I don’t understand.
That ship, Salvage 2! It’s still coming for us! There’s definitely nowhere safer than here?
No. This never happens.
Space suits, then. Have you got any space suits?
In the lockers.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 27
SCENE 21. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
First bit of good news all day: system’s recognised my authorisation codes.
More than I do.
I’m sending override commands to Salvage 2.
(CALLING) Security! (TO JESSICA) Jessica, get out of here.
No response.
What? Your answer is you won’t answer?
No response from Salvage 2. Lose the attitude, Slim — I’m the one here legally, right now you’re work experience. Get me control of Salvage 2.
I’m trying-! It’s like there’s something in Salvage 2 counteracting every command we give it!
(OVER SPEAKER) Hello? Anyone there?
What? Who’s that? Where’s it coming from?
(TO JESSICA) I don’t know. TV reporter maybe. Run those overrides again, I’m holding nav-con.
Right.
(OVER SPEAKER) No, this must be the right frequency. Hello, mission control, this is the Doctor, I’m aboard Salvage 2.
It’s nonsense. Nobody’s there. Turn him off.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 28
(OVER SPEAKER) Release nav-con to me. Oh, and flight now, I had control of flight.
I just got control of flight right now. He’s real.
No, he isn’t. (INTO HEADSET) Clear this line! We have an emergency!
Look at the monitors. It’s seconds from hitting the station.
(OVER SPEAKER) I haven’t time, release controls.
(INTO HEADSET) Salvage 2 is automated! There’s no one on board!
(OVER SPEAKER) Wrong. Look, if you don’t want to help, at least stop fiddling.
(TO JESSICA) What are you doing?
I’m stopping fiddling.
(OVER SPEAKER) Thank you!
He really is there.
For how much longer?
Impact with space station in three...
It won’t hit.
. two...
Not with me in charge.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 29
One. Impact.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 30
SCENE 22. INT. MANDELA — OBSERVATION MODULE
(THE SMASH OF SALVAGE 2 HITTING THE STATION. IT’S NOT A HEAD-ON
IT CLIPS THE MODULE THAT FLIP AND JYOTI ARE IN. THEY’RE TRYING TO GET SPACESUITS ON. )
Jyoti! Leave the camera!
Just a sec, this is too good.
F/X VIOLENT HISSING OF AIR ESCAPING, WIND-LIKE ROAR
Listen! That means we’ve been punctured, doesn’t it?
F/X: ALARMS
Yeah. Air venting into space. Oh, I so hope this camera is 3D.
Put your helmet on. Do it now.
(PUTTING ON HELMET) Alright, alright.
And show me how to do mine. — Gah, I can’t move in this suit! Why’s mine twice the size of yours?
(HELMETED) Hold still! (FIXING FLIP’S HELMET THROUGH:) It’s just what we had. You got a Baumgartner, I got a basic Aldrin.
(HELMETED) But you keep them topped up with oxygen, right?
(HELMETED) Not really, no.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 31
SCENE 23. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
Looks like the impact has clipped a Mandela module. Bad news for anyone in it, but it looks like the rest of the station is safe.
Salvage 2 showing course change. Bit late, but it’s changing. Reaching ejection point.
Okay. You can stand down now, Slim.
I’m not going anywhere.
(ALOUD) Attention, everyone! There’s a saboteur on staff. I want everyone out of mission control.
(AUDIBLE CONSTERNATION) Is she mad?/ That’s insane!
(ALOUD) I said everyone! (CLAPS HANDS) Go on, move it! There’s a security team waiting outside. Report for debriefing now or I’ll have you arrested! Don’t think I don’t mean it!
GRUMBLE, SHUFFLING OUT THROUGH:
Same goes for you, Slim. The mission’s over.
Please, not now! We’ve reached the ejection point, but there’s been no ejection. We’re going to lose Salvage 2!
Forget Salvage 2. It’s dead, gone, finished. You need to start thinking about the inquiry into this mess.
That man may still be aboard, whoever he was!
If I were you, Slim, I'd keep things simple. There was no mysterious stranger aboard Salvage 2. There can’t have been.
Then how do you explain it?
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 32
Maybe he was the saboteur, hacking into our comms.
Do you think so...?
Could be he’s right inside this building.
(F/X TARDIS MATERIALISATION, JUST OFF. NB: LAST OF THE
HAS GONE BY NOW)
Is — is that something to do with you?
I don’t believe it...
DOCTOR RUNS OUT.
Oh, so it is you. Jessica Allaway. Thought I recognised the voice.
Have we met?
Well, we have now. (TO SALIM) You — you must be the mission controller, is that right?
I’m Salim Jahangir, but —
Yes, well — next time, Salim, program some leeway in your spacecraft’s payload parameters, would you? My TARDIS was a little heavier than a satellite.
(CALLING) Security!
(CALLING) Security!
(CALLING) Security!
BEAT. SECURITY DOESN'T ARRIVE.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 33
Must be on a tea break.
Busy processing the technical staff. We’ve got a saboteur.
I can see you’ve got a lot of problems here but trust me, I am not one of them. Please, let me at the controls.
(TO DOCTOR) Salvage 2 is gone. What exactly do you think you can do, mister, eY...?
F/X DOCTOR TAKES OVER THE CONTROLS. TAPPING AWAY THROUGH:
Doctor. I did say. Now, do you want to save Salvage 2 or not?
Alright, go ahead.
Are you serious?
It’s an expensive machine. It’s lost now, but if he really thinks he can salvage it...
And you trust him? — Oh, oh, of course. It’s because he’s British!
If you two could bear to put your obvious differences aside for just one moment — I’m going to need a radio link to the Mandela. Can you do that?
(INTO HEADSET) I-S-R-A Mission Control calling Mandela. Come in, Mandela Station.
No answer.
(READING OFF SCREEN) There’s computer traffic, but it’s all bad. Says they’ve lost a module.
I knew it had hit the station. I felt it. But a whole module? Which one?
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 34
Wait... Good news, it was just observation.
Oh, no! Flip..!
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 35
SCENE 24. EXT. SPACE
FLIP AND JYOTI IN SPACE, FLOATING
(F/X FLIP’S SPACE-SUIT AND HER BREATHING. DEFINITELY 2001 WITH A BIT MORE PANIC.)
Breathe, Flip. You’re floating in space. Happens all the time. (LOUDER) Jyoti? Show me again. I can’t see which buttons you meant.
(F/X PRESSES BUTTONS ON THE ARM OF HER SUIT; IT BLEEPS AND
JYOTI’S VOICE STARTS)
- ellow, the yellow button switches on the radio. Green to talk to me.
Gotcha. Green for go. Are you okay?
I’m fantastic. I saved the camera! Give me a wave.
Hello. Can you see the module?
It’s floating away behind you. But it’s the space station we need, not the module.
Right. Okay. (BEAT) Is that footage being seen anywhere? Does anyone know we’re out here?
No. And radios are seriously short-range. These suits are just module spares from when it was fitted. I’ve got forty-six minutes’ oxygen, what about you?
I don’t know how to tell.
Hold down green and blue buttons for a sec.
F/X FLIP’S HELMET SWITCHES ON A HEADS-UP DISPLAY
Wow, television. It says oxygen fifty-three minutes — and now everything’s gone red.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 36
(INTERRUPTED) — breaking up. We’re drifting too far apart.
Jyoti! How do we get to the station? (BEAT) Jyoti?
- idea.
(RELIEF) Great!
- no idea at all —
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 37
SCENE 25. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
(THE DOCTOR HURRYING ABOUT THE CONTROLS, TYPING AND SEARCHING
WHAT HE NEEDS NEXT. )
I need a database of everything in orbit. Everything up there that isn’t junk. Have you got that?
Spaceguard. If it’s not on Spaceguard, and it’s bigger than a fist, NASA tracks it as space junk.
As a matter of fact, I helped get Spaceguard started.
(WITHERING) Of course you did.

JESSICA: No response from Salvage 2. Lose the attitude, Slim — I’m the one here legally, right now you’re work experience. Get me control of Salvage 2.
SALIM: I’m trying-! It’s like there’s something in Salvage 2 counteracting every command we give it!
DOCTOR: (OVER SPEAKER) Hello? Anyone there?
JESSICA: What? Who’s that? Where’s it coming from?
SALIM: (TO JESSICA) I don’t know. TV reporter maybe. Run those overrides again, I’m holding nav-con.
JESSICA: Right.
DOCTOR: (OVER SPEAKER) No, this must be the right frequency. Hello, mission control, this is the Doctor, I’m aboard Salvage 2.
SALIM: It’s nonsense. Nobody’s there. Turn him off.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 28
DOCTOR: (OVER SPEAKER) Release nav-con to me. Oh, and flight now, I had control of flight.
JESSICA: I just got control of flight right now. He’s real.
SALIM: No, he isn’t. (INTO HEADSET) Clear this line! We have an emergency!
JESSICA: Look at the monitors. It’s seconds from hitting the station.
DOCTOR: (OVER SPEAKER) I haven’t time, release controls.
SALIM: (INTO HEADSET) Salvage 2 is automated! There’s no one on board!
DOCTOR: (OVER SPEAKER) Wrong. Look, if you don’t want to help, at least stop fiddling.
SALIM: (TO JESSICA) What are you doing?
JESSICA: I’m stopping fiddling.
DOCTOR: (OVER SPEAKER) Thank you!
SALIM: He really is there.
JESSICA: For how much longer?
SALIM: Impact with space station in three...
JESSICA: It won’t hit.
SALIM: . two...
JESSICA: Not with me in charge.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 29
SALIM: One. Impact.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 30
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 22. INT. MANDELA — OBSERVATION MODULE
DOCTOR WHO: (THE SMASH OF SALVAGE 2 HITTING THE STATION. IT’S NOT A HEAD-ON
COLLISION: IT CLIPS THE MODULE THAT FLIP AND JYOTI ARE IN. THEY’RE TRYING TO GET SPACESUITS ON. )
FLIP: Jyoti! Leave the camera!
JYOTI: Just a sec, this is too good.
FLIP: Listen! That means we’ve been punctured, doesn’t it?
JYOTI: Yeah. Air venting into space. Oh, I so hope this camera is 3D.
FLIP: Put your helmet on. Do it now.
JYOTI: (PUTTING ON HELMET) Alright, alright.
FLIP: And show me how to do mine. — Gah, I can’t move in this suit! Why’s mine twice the size of yours?
JYOTI: (HELMETED) Hold still! (FIXING FLIP’S HELMET THROUGH:) It’s just what we had. You got a Baumgartner, I got a basic Aldrin.
FLIP: (HELMETED) But you keep them topped up with oxygen, right?
JYOTI: (HELMETED) Not really, no.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 31
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 23. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
JESSICA: Looks like the impact has clipped a Mandela module. Bad news for anyone in it, but it looks like the rest of the station is safe.
SALIM: Salvage 2 showing course change. Bit late, but it’s changing. Reaching ejection point.
JESSICA: Okay. You can stand down now, Slim.
SALIM: I’m not going anywhere.
JESSICA: (ALOUD) Attention, everyone! There’s a saboteur on staff. I want everyone out of mission control.
TECHNICIANS: (AUDIBLE CONSTERNATION) Is she mad?/ That’s insane!
JESSICA: (ALOUD) I said everyone! (CLAPS HANDS) Go on, move it! There’s a security team waiting outside. Report for debriefing now or I’ll have you arrested! Don’t think I don’t mean it!
JESSICA: Same goes for you, Slim. The mission’s over.
SALIM: Please, not now! We’ve reached the ejection point, but there’s been no ejection. We’re going to lose Salvage 2!
JESSICA: Forget Salvage 2. It’s dead, gone, finished. You need to start thinking about the inquiry into this mess.
SALIM: That man may still be aboard, whoever he was!
JESSICA: If I were you, Slim, I'd keep things simple. There was no mysterious stranger aboard Salvage 2. There can’t have been.
SALIM: Then how do you explain it?
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 32
JESSICA: Maybe he was the saboteur, hacking into our comms.
SALIM: Do you think so...?
JESSICA: Could be he’s right inside this building.
JESSICA: (F/X TARDIS MATERIALISATION, JUST OFF. NB: LAST OF THE
TECHNICIANS: HAS GONE BY NOW)
SALIM: Is — is that something to do with you?
JESSICA: I don’t believe it...
DOCTOR: Oh, so it is you. Jessica Allaway. Thought I recognised the voice.
JESSICA: Have we met?
DOCTOR: Well, we have now. (TO SALIM) You — you must be the mission controller, is that right?
SALIM: I’m Salim Jahangir, but —
DOCTOR: Yes, well — next time, Salim, program some leeway in your spacecraft’s payload parameters, would you? My TARDIS was a little heavier than a satellite.
SALIM: (CALLING) Security!
JESSICA: (CALLING) Security!
DOCTOR: (CALLING) Security!
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 33
DOCTOR: Must be on a tea break.
JESSICA: Busy processing the technical staff. We’ve got a saboteur.
DOCTOR: I can see you’ve got a lot of problems here but trust me, I am not one of them. Please, let me at the controls.
SALIM: (TO DOCTOR) Salvage 2 is gone. What exactly do you think you can do, mister, eY...?
DOCTOR: Doctor. I did say. Now, do you want to save Salvage 2 or not?
JESSICA: Alright, go ahead.
SALIM: Are you serious?
JESSICA: It’s an expensive machine. It’s lost now, but if he really thinks he can salvage it...
SALIM: And you trust him? — Oh, oh, of course. It’s because he’s British!
DOCTOR: If you two could bear to put your obvious differences aside for just one moment — I’m going to need a radio link to the Mandela. Can you do that?
SALIM: (INTO HEADSET) I-S-R-A Mission Control calling Mandela. Come in, Mandela Station.
JESSICA: No answer.
SALIM: (READING OFF SCREEN) There’s computer traffic, but it’s all bad. Says they’ve lost a module.
DOCTOR: I knew it had hit the station. I felt it. But a whole module? Which one?
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 34
SALIM: Wait... Good news, it was just observation.
DOCTOR: Oh, no! Flip..!
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 35
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 24. EXT. SPACE
DOCTOR WHO: (F/X FLIP’S SPACE-SUIT AND HER BREATHING. DEFINITELY 2001 WITH A BIT MORE PANIC.)
FLIP: Breathe, Flip. You’re floating in space. Happens all the time. (LOUDER) Jyoti? Show me again. I can’t see which buttons you meant.
FLIP: (F/X PRESSES BUTTONS ON THE ARM OF HER SUIT; IT BLEEPS AND
IMMEDIATELY: JYOTI’S VOICE STARTS)
JYOTI: - ellow, the yellow button switches on the radio. Green to talk to me.
FLIP: Gotcha. Green for go. Are you okay?
JYOTI: I’m fantastic. I saved the camera! Give me a wave.
FLIP: Hello. Can you see the module?
JYOTI: It’s floating away behind you. But it’s the space station we need, not the module.
FLIP: Right. Okay. (BEAT) Is that footage being seen anywhere? Does anyone know we’re out here?
JYOTI: No. And radios are seriously short-range. These suits are just module spares from when it was fitted. I’ve got forty-six minutes’ oxygen, what about you?
FLIP: I don’t know how to tell.
JYOTI: Hold down green and blue buttons for a sec.
FLIP: Wow, television. It says oxygen fifty-three minutes — and now everything’s gone red.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 36
JYOTI: (INTERRUPTED) — breaking up. We’re drifting too far apart.
FLIP: Jyoti! How do we get to the station? (BEAT) Jyoti?
JYOTI: - idea.
FLIP: (RELIEF) Great!
JYOTI: - no idea at all —
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 37
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 25. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
DOCTOR WHO: (THE DOCTOR HURRYING ABOUT THE CONTROLS, TYPING AND SEARCHING
FOR: WHAT HE NEEDS NEXT. )
DOCTOR: I need a database of everything in orbit. Everything up there that isn’t junk. Have you got that?
SALIM: Spaceguard. If it’s not on Spaceguard, and it’s bigger than a fist, NASA tracks it as space junk.
DOCTOR: As a matter of fact, I helped get Spaceguard started.
JESSICA: (WITHERING) Of course you did.
DOCTOR: Spaceguard systems online. Good. Could you all keep quiet for just one second? I need to get this into my head.
SALIM: What? You’re going to memorise the orbital database?
JESSICA: Five thousand active satellites and fifteen thousand pieces of junk?
DOCTOR: I did say give me a second.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit)
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 26. TV: VERY BAD SOAP
TV SOAP ACTRESS: Oh, Kenneth! What if my husband comes home early?
TV SOAP ACTOR: I already have, Alishia.
TV SOAP ACTRESS: Jonathan! I can explain, I was —
DOCTOR: Page 38
DOCTOR: (ON SCREEN) Oh, I’ve seen this one. Kenneth has set the whole thing up to blackmail Alishia into signing over the corporation but what neither of them realises is that he’s really her twin
DOCTOR: brother. Mind if I borrow your satellite?
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 39
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 27. TV NEWS BULLETIN
MELISSA: [TV REPORTER]:
MELISSA: — been no official word from the police but local sources say the entire football team has been missing since yesterday evening.
DOCTOR: Exclusive for Newshub Nine. They’re all in the Fox and Goose, Mumbai. Just need to borrow something, thank you.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 40
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 28. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
DOCTOR: Right. Both of these satellites are in the Clarke belt. Supposedly geo-stationary but they will have just a little course-correction propellant and they’re exactly where I need them.
SALIM: Spaceguard reporting SuperSoap satellite deviating from orbit.
JESSICA: Yes, and I’ve got the Newshub Nine satellite increasing altitude.
SALIM: They’re going to hit each other!
DOCTOR: Oh, I do hope so.
SALIM: I’ve got visual from cameras on one of —
SALIM: (F/X ALARMS STOP. ‘BANG’ AS SATELLITES COLLIDE [NOT STRICTLY ACCURATE, BUT]. )
SALIM: Oh, I felt that one.
JESSICA: Do you know how much just one of those satellites costs?
DOCTOR: Flip is worth more. Now, I need something in a low-Earth orbit...
JESSICA: Spaceguard says an old Soviet spy satellite is increasing altitude. It’s going to be in their path.
DOCTOR: One satellite hits another, hits another, hits another.
SALIM: And what is the point? We’re supposed to be clearing up space junk, not making more.
JESSICA: Is this you, Doctor? French elliptical orbiter firing thrusters.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 41
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 29. EXT. SPACE
JYOTI: Just a sec, we've spun, I’ve got you framed just right with the Space station over your shoulder.
FLIP: Wonderful.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 42
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 30. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
DOCTOR: Everything’s working but this one. Why can’t I get into this?
SALIM: Which one are you after?
DOCTOR: This. Whacking great thing, just above Envisat. Odd cylindrical shape.
SALIM: (LYING) I do not know what it is.
DOCTOR: Really? Because from what I can see, it would have been directly in Salvage 2’s orbital path.
JESSICA: (THOUGHTFUL) Like whoever sabotaged the flight computer wanted Salvage 2 to hit it..
DOCTOR: Well, whatever it is, it’s the last domino. Impact imminent.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 43
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 31. EXT. SPACE
FLIP: It’s the Doctor! He’s alive!
JYOTI: Where?
FLIP: Look! Spin around. There’s like this whole string of satellites ramming into each another, knocking the next one on! Who else but the Doctor would think of that?
JYOTI: What? Think of what?
FLIP: He’s sending a satellite our way. He’s sending us a satellite to grab onto! Doctor, you are brilliant!
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 44
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 32. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
DOCTOR: Do you know, I think I did something like this with a single cricket ball once? I had no imagination then.
JESSICA: Impact in ten.
SALIM: Sixty satellites now moving out of the way. People have finally caught on to what you’re doing.
DOCTOR: Doesn’t matter now, so long as none cross in front of this last one in the next — Jessica?
JESSICA: Four seconds. Three. Two...
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 45
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 33. INT. SPACE
FLIP: There, the big cylinder one. It’s going to be knocked our way any moment. Get ready to grab hold.
FLIP: (F/X SMALL SATELLITE COLLIDES WITH BIG CYLINDRICAL ONE. THE
CYLINDRICAL: ONE IS ‘SCAVENGER’. IT ABSORBS THE IMPACT)
JYOTI: No good. The cylinder one isn’t moving. It must have just — absorbed the impact somehow.
FLIP: How’s that even possible? I swear I could feel the wallop from here.
FLIP: (F/X ELECTRICAL PULSE AS THE SCAVENGER’S ENGINE’S GRIND INTO LIFE)
JYOTI: No, wait, it’s moving.
FLIP: It’s turning. It’s lighting up. Jyoti, I think its engines have started!
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 46
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 34. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
JESSICA: The cylindrical one, what’s it doing?
DOCTOR: Whatever it is, I'd say that impact gave it some sort of kick start.
SALIM: (RECOGNITION) Oh no. No, no, no...
SCAVENGER: (OVER SYSTEMS) Stand by. Scavenger systems rebooting. Navigation. Propulsion. Weapons.
JESSICA: Is that what I think it is? Some zombie satellite is speaking to us?
DOCTOR: Undead, you might say. “Scavenger”, it called itself. Interesting.
SECURITY GUY: Ma'am, we’ve secured the building.
DOCTOR: Oh look, security. Tea break’s over, I take it.
JESSICA: (TO SECURITY) Lock down mission control.
SECURITY GUY: Already done, Ma’am. Armed men on every entrance.
SALIM: (TO HIMSELF) Not this. Not this again.
JESSICA: (SHARP) What did you say...?
SCAVENGER: (OVER SPEAKER) Weapons online.
DOCTOR: Whatever this “Scavenger” is, we need to stop it before it opens fire on Flip and Jyoti!
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 47
SCAVENGER: (OVER SPEAKER) Firing.
SCAVENGER: END OF PART ONE
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 48

elements.text: PART TWO
(OVER SPEAKER) Weapons online.
Whatever this “Scavenger” is, we need to stop it before it
opens fire on Flip and Jyoti!
(OVER SPEAKER) Firing.
F/X OVER SPEAKER: LASERS STARTING TO FIRE
CUT TO:
SCENE 35. EXT. SPACE
F/X SCAVENGER FIRING RIGHT IN FRONT OF FLIP AND JYOTI
F/X HELMET FX ON FLIP AND JYOTI
I’m in Star Wars! Jyoti, the light’s blinding me. Can you see?
(THROUGH FLIP’S HELMET SPEAKER) Scavenger securing defence perimeter.
Wait, I heard that. It’s talking? Jyoti, point your camera at it right now.
I’m uploading! Going to get my footage straight into the cloud. At least it will survive even if we don’t.
Let’s see if we can’t get you an interview. (CALLING) Hello! Satellite thing?
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 49
SCENE 36. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
Salim, watch the Haystack radar monitor. Jessica, get rid of your security.
(F/X COCKING GUN) You talking to me?
(TO SECURITY) It’s okay, [1’11 deal with this]
(TO SECURITY) I’m talking about you.
Doctor, my security stays. (TO SECURITY) No shooting.
Ma’am.
Thank you.
You can blame a corpse but living scapegoats look better on TV.
Doctor, just ignore her. This is my mission control. Indian mission control.
This whole project only got off the ground because of British money. British expertise. You wouldn’t be anywhere without us.
(IGNORING HER) Look at the Haystack imaging. Live satellites and space junk alike, it’s all disappearing around this Scavenger.
What do we do?
The thought occurs: if Scavenger can speak, surely it can listen too. (INTO MIC) Doctor calling Scavenger. Shut down your systems.
(TO JESSICA) Do you want to know what British investment bought?
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 50
I do know. I was on the Board that authorised the payment. Why’d you think the British Government hired me?
Your people skills?
You scratched their back, they scratched yours.
Listen, friend: our money didn’t buy sabotage on Salvage 2. It didn’t buy smashing a module off the Mandela. It didn’t buy stranding astronauts in space.
Could you move a touch to your left? I’m going to need that keyboard.
It bought the coffee machine. Thank you very much for that. It’s been vital.
(MORE TO SELF) I need to find the phrase that makes this thing talk. That way I won’t have to listen to the pair of you bickering. (INTO MIC) Scavenger, try this. Respond with status.
(OVER SPEAKER) Processing.
That’s progress.
(OVER SPEAKER) Identification: Scavenger. Systems resuming. Failure detected on visual. Failure on emitters. Failure on navigation control. Failure on repair systems. Seeking replacements.
Scavenger, stop firing. All weapons to standby.
BEAT
(OVER SPEAKER) Cycling emitters. Calculating firing solution.
Firing.
Well, it might’ve worked.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 51
SCENE 37. EXT. SPACE
F/X HELMET FX THROUGHOUT
Scavenger! My name’s Flip. Can you hear me? (BEAT) I don’t think it’s listening to me.
F/X LASER BLAST
Damn, that was a near miss. I’1ll do a data dump while we’ve still got a working camera.
Where will that go?
Dumps to the cloud, triggers a backup on the systems at Control and the Mandela.
I think this thing has stopped firing. How long have you got left on oxygen?
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 52
SCENE 38. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
I think it’s stopped firing.
F/X BLIP
Spoke too soon.
No, that’s a message. (READS) Salvage 2’s restarted.
Where is it? Can we send it to pick up Flip?
Completely the opposite side of the planet. Forty minutes until it’s in position.
So, Salvage 2 is safe. Pity about our friends in space, but overall I think we’ve contained the situation.
We?
A triumph for Anglo-Indian co-operation.
Jessica, what if I told you that my friends in space are a British national and an Indian astronaut? Phillipa Jackson and Jyoti Cutler, in orbit and in need of rescue.
Jessica, look at the monitors. TV news. It’s going mad out there.
I’d say they need a statement from someone in charge.
Exactly.
Don’t think I don’t know what you’re doing. But you’re also right. This is the perfect moment to announce that the Indian government has handed I-S-R-A over to us.
Have they?
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 53
Once I’ve reminded them of the small print in the contract, yes.
SHE EXITS. DOOR OPENS-AND-CLOSES.
Now, then, Salim, what’s this cloud backup that’s started?
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 54
SCENE 39. EXT. ISRA SPACE CENTRE
(FADE UP PRESS MOB: CAMERAS, SHOUTING, QUESTIONING. JESSICA IN
ELEMENT. )
Here! Ms Allaway! Jessica! Over here! [ETC]
Naturally, I can’t release the names of the astronauts but my very best man is working on saving them.
[TV REPORTER]: And what about these reports of sabotage? Is the mission controller to blame?
No comment.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 55
SCENE 40. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
F/X VIDEO SOUNDS — FROM PREVIOUS SCENE
Just a sec, we’ve spun, I’ve got you framed just right with the space station over your shoulder.
Oh, lovely.
Fast forward for me, Salim.
F/X FOOTAGE ZOOMS ALONG ON FAST FORWARD
The file hasn’t finished downloading yet, it’1ll cut out at some
point.
Stop there. Back a little.
F/X FROM SCENE 33:
No, wait, it’s moving.
It’s turning. It’s lighting up. Jyoti, I think its engines have started!
So that’s what it looks like.
It’s bigger than I expected.
I think it’s smaller.
Wind back to the impact. I want to calculate its mass.
REWIND, PLAY, BAM
That’s hard to watch.
Do you know, I think it must be hollow? Still very strong.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 56
What are those markings? It might almost be Sanskrit.
It’s not an Earth language. Whatever Scavenger is... it’s alien.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 57
SCENE 41. EXT. SPACE
F/X HELMET FX THROUGHOUT
Ten minutes oxygen left. You on sixteen or seventeen?
Plenty of time. And Jyoti, I don’t see anyone else floating around out here. We saved some people on the Mandela. You and me. What else are we here for if not that?
[PRONOUNCED ‘CHAA-T’, LIKE ‘CHART’ WITHOUT THE R] Samosa Chaat, for one. Meeting new people —
Um, hello?
- creating something worthwhile, you know?
I know.
I was going to be a film producer. Family forced me into science. I had all my life for the movies, they said. “Get a profession, see the world.”
Yes, family’s never fun. But bet yours are proud of you.
Weren’t yours?
They were all “why aren’t you a boy?” And then they had one. I left. It’s 2071, they might even have noticed by now. And I wish they’d been bothered enough to say “see the world”.
Why?
Look down, Jyoti. One world, job done.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 58
SCENE 42. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
We’ve got the whole file now.
Play the last moments for me, would you?
F/X VIDEO NOISES — FROM SCENE 37:
I think this thing has stopped firing. How long have you got left on oxygen?
That’s where it ends.
And that’s my cue.
I’ve got Salvage 2 heading their way.
No. They’re low on oxygen. I can get to them faster than Salvage 2 can.
Seriously?
ENTER JESSICA
(APPROACHING FROM OFF) You’re not planning on going anywhere, I hope?
Ms Allaway. It’s quite alright, there’s no need to thank me. If it’s all the same to you, I’1ll just be on my way in my funny blue box.
THE DOCTOR HEADS FOR THE TARDIS
Security.
(INTERCEPTING THE DOCTOR) Sir — Ma’am would rather you stayed.
Ma’am insists.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 59
At gunpoint? Madam, I enjoy a good exchange of opinions but if you’re going to threaten me...
You thought that was a threat? I was being nice. This is a threat: you’re an asset, Doctor, but you’re unauthorised. So far the one has balanced the other, but if you try to leave, you will be shot.
Seriously, Jessica. There’s no need for all this.
More to the point, there’s no time. (TO JESSICA) People’s lives are at risk, you do realise that?
Okay. You want to talk about lives. How about everyone on the Mandela?
They’re fine. Probably.
Computer chatter says they’ve restored gyros, they’ve got EVAsS repairing some systems. They lost a module but everything else is okay.
But where is that module? This module that’s easily ten times the size of the Envisat zombie satellite. It’s somewhere in orbit — and it’s a very, very big addition to all the junk up there.
She’s right, Salim.

Don’t sound so shocked. If that module smashes into the Mandela, nothing will save that station or any of the people aboard. So, Doctor, evidently you know more about orbital mechanics than is healthy and I need that right now. Your job is protecting the Mandela. From the module and from this Scavenger.
Your own database will be tracking both. My job is rescuing Flip and Jyoti.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 60
I’m coming to that. Slim — I saw the look on your face when that ‘Scavenger’ first appeared, I’ve a feeling you know a whole lot more about it that you’re letting on.
Rubbish.
I confess, Salim, your reaction did seem a little... odd.

Exactly. So what’s happening in just a few minutes is, you’re going to tell me and the Doctor everything you know. But first, I’m going to run a visual inspection on the Mandela by diverting a spy satellite to it. Then, the Doctor can fly it to rescue his friends. And didn’t I seem like the bad guy?
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 61
SCENE 43. EXT. SPACE
F/X HELMETS THROUGHOUT
Flip, what’s your heads-up say about your suit?
Not a clue. There’s a thing saying PSI. I thought that was a TV show.
You might be able to jump.
Sorry?
I can’t, my suit won’t take the pressure. But yours is a Baumgartner, you got the full kit. I should’ve thought of it before. What’s your oxygen?
Hang on, did you see that?
Is it firing again?
No, behind it. I thought — now it’s above it, climbing, yes, there’s a — look, you can see it when it crosses the Earth, there’s a black satellite moving.
It’s very close to the Scavenger.
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 62
SCENE 44. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
You getting the hang of flying Sid, Doctor?
(AT CONTROLS OF SPY SATELLITE, FLYIG IT TO FLIP & JYOTI) Sid-? Is that what they call spy satellites, these days?
You’re dead on course.
One more burn in three... two...
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 63
SCENE 45. EXT. SPACE
F/X HELMET FX THROUGHOUT. SATELLITE ENGINE BURN CLOSE BY
Right, Jyoti, reach out for me. We’re only going to get a second.
I’m on three minutes’ oxygen, it’s not worth it.
It isn’t over until three minutes are over. That satellite is coming our way and we’re grabbing it, okay?
Then what?
We’re going home. Mandela station or bust.
(OVER SPEAKERS) Identification: Scavenger. Systems resumed. Failure detected on visual. Visual equipment supply detected.
Scavenger’s moving! Oh, why can’t we reach anyone?
SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 64
SCENE 46. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL

FLIP: They were all “why aren’t you a boy?” And then they had one. I left. It’s 2071, they might even have noticed by now. And I wish they’d been bothered enough to say “see the world”.
JYOTI: Why?
FLIP: Look down, Jyoti. One world, job done.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 58
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 42. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
SALIM: We’ve got the whole file now.
DOCTOR: Play the last moments for me, would you?
FLIP: I think this thing has stopped firing. How long have you got left on oxygen?
SALIM: That’s where it ends.
DOCTOR: And that’s my cue.
SALIM: I’ve got Salvage 2 heading their way.
DOCTOR: No. They’re low on oxygen. I can get to them faster than Salvage 2 can.
SALIM: Seriously?
JESSICA: (APPROACHING FROM OFF) You’re not planning on going anywhere, I hope?
DOCTOR: Ms Allaway. It’s quite alright, there’s no need to thank me. If it’s all the same to you, I’1ll just be on my way in my funny blue box.
JESSICA: Security.
SECURITY GUY: (INTERCEPTING THE DOCTOR) Sir — Ma’am would rather you stayed.
JESSICA: Ma’am insists.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 59
DOCTOR: At gunpoint? Madam, I enjoy a good exchange of opinions but if you’re going to threaten me...
JESSICA: You thought that was a threat? I was being nice. This is a threat: you’re an asset, Doctor, but you’re unauthorised. So far the one has balanced the other, but if you try to leave, you will be shot.
SALIM: Seriously, Jessica. There’s no need for all this.
DOCTOR: More to the point, there’s no time. (TO JESSICA) People’s lives are at risk, you do realise that?
JESSICA: Okay. You want to talk about lives. How about everyone on the Mandela?
DOCTOR: They’re fine. Probably.
SALIM: Computer chatter says they’ve restored gyros, they’ve got EVAsS repairing some systems. They lost a module but everything else is okay.
JESSICA: But where is that module? This module that’s easily ten times the size of the Envisat zombie satellite. It’s somewhere in orbit — and it’s a very, very big addition to all the junk up there.
DOCTOR: She’s right, Salim.
JESSICA: Don’t sound so shocked. If that module smashes into the Mandela, nothing will save that station or any of the people aboard. So, Doctor, evidently you know more about orbital mechanics than is healthy and I need that right now. Your job is protecting the Mandela. From the module and from this Scavenger.
DOCTOR: Your own database will be tracking both. My job is rescuing Flip and Jyoti.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 60
JESSICA: I’m coming to that. Slim — I saw the look on your face when that ‘Scavenger’ first appeared, I’ve a feeling you know a whole lot more about it that you’re letting on.
SALIM: Rubbish.
DOCTOR: I confess, Salim, your reaction did seem a little... odd.
JESSICA: Exactly. So what’s happening in just a few minutes is, you’re going to tell me and the Doctor everything you know. But first, I’m going to run a visual inspection on the Mandela by diverting a spy satellite to it. Then, the Doctor can fly it to rescue his friends. And didn’t I seem like the bad guy?
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 61
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 43. EXT. SPACE
JYOTI: Flip, what’s your heads-up say about your suit?
FLIP: Not a clue. There’s a thing saying PSI. I thought that was a TV show.
JYOTI: You might be able to jump.
FLIP: Sorry?
JYOTI: I can’t, my suit won’t take the pressure. But yours is a Baumgartner, you got the full kit. I should’ve thought of it before. What’s your oxygen?
FLIP: Hang on, did you see that?
JYOTI: Is it firing again?
FLIP: No, behind it. I thought — now it’s above it, climbing, yes, there’s a — look, you can see it when it crosses the Earth, there’s a black satellite moving.
JYOTI: It’s very close to the Scavenger.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 62
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 44. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
JESSICA: You getting the hang of flying Sid, Doctor?
DOCTOR: (AT CONTROLS OF SPY SATELLITE, FLYIG IT TO FLIP & JYOTI) Sid-? Is that what they call spy satellites, these days?
SALIM: You’re dead on course.
DOCTOR: One more burn in three... two...
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 63
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 45. EXT. SPACE
FLIP: Right, Jyoti, reach out for me. We’re only going to get a second.
JYOTI: I’m on three minutes’ oxygen, it’s not worth it.
FLIP: It isn’t over until three minutes are over. That satellite is coming our way and we’re grabbing it, okay?
JYOTI: Then what?
FLIP: We’re going home. Mandela station or bust.
SCAVENGER: (OVER SPEAKERS) Identification: Scavenger. Systems resumed. Failure detected on visual. Visual equipment supply detected.
FLIP: Scavenger’s moving! Oh, why can’t we reach anyone?
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 64
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 46. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
SCAVENGER: (OVER SPEAKERS) Recovery and replacement program activated.
SALIM: Look.
JESSICA: It’s moving fast. There’s a lot of visual equipment on Sid. It’s detected the camera gear and it wants it.
DOCTOR: That’s rather impressive. I wonder how it knows?
SALIM: If we’ve got cameras, why don’t we use them?
DOCTOR: What a good idea.
DOCTOR: Would you look at that? Now that’s precision flying, if I do say so myself. Perfectly lined up, it’1ll fly right beside the Mandela. Switching to 180 rear camera. Oh.
JESSICA: There they are. Our two astronauts. Scavenger’s closing in.
DOCTOR: It’s gaining on them. — There, that one must be Flip. Good girl! She’s got Jyoti in a position to grab on.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 65
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 47. EXT. SPACE
FLIP: Reach for the satellite! Get a hold!
FLIP: Whoa, that’s a punch to the ribs. Jyoti? Are you on?
JYOTI: (PANTING) Yeah. — I think I’m going to throw up in my suit.
FLIP: Lovely.
FLIP: (F/X LASER BLAST FROM OFF — THE SCAVENGER SHOOTING ITS
TELEPORT: BEAM AT THEM; SEE LAHORE FLASHBACK SCENES 54-56)
FLIP: What the-? Something’s shooting pink lasers at us. Get your head down, Jyoti, and stay at the front!
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 66
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 48. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
DOCTOR: Where’ve they got to-? They’re in space suits, they must have comms.
SALIM: Can’t raise them on the radio, sorry.
JESSICA: Look at the rear view. The whole screen’s glowing a kind of pink.
DOCTOR: All forward motion has been arrested. That beam from Scavenger, it’s holding Sid. Cycle the cameras, are Flip and Jyoti okay?
SALIM: No sign on the perimeter or rear cameras.
JESSICA: They’ve let go. Look, on forward view. They’ve let go and they’re carrying on toward the Mandela.
DOCTOR: Momentum! And she says she never paid attention in school.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 67
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 49. EXT. SPACE
JYOTI: (INCREASINGLY WEAK. SHALLOW BREATHING) Can’t see my heads-up display. My helmet’s fogged up.
FLIP: Listen, just hold on to me, Jyoti, and turn when I do. The momentum’s gonna carry us all the way to the —
COMMANDER GABBARD: (OVER HELMET SPEAKER) Commander Gabbard, Mandela station, to astronaut. Come in Jyoti. Is that you? Opening the airlock now.
FLIP: Hear that, Jyoti? Almost there. (BEAT) Jyoti? (BEAT) Jyoti! Stay conscious, just a little longer. One more minute and we’1l be on board the Mandela, you’1ll see. (BEAT) Here it comes now, the airlock. Just let go of me, and grab a hold.
JYOTI: (RASPING) No strength left.
FLIP: Let go of me. Let go!
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 68
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 50. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
DOCTOR: They’re opening an airlock on the Mandela. (BEAT) And that camera’s gone, just at the good bit. Let’s try the rear view, see if Scavenger’s taken that yet.
SALIM: I’m glad your friend is alright.
DOCTOR: Thank you. (RE SCAVENGER) It really is fascinating. Part mechanical, part sonic, part laser. Taking what it needs from the spy satellite. It genuinely is scavenging.
SALIM: We have to find a way to stop it. It won’t stop at cameras, it...
JESSICA: Uh-huh.
DOCTOR: You do know about this Scavenger — don’t you, Salim?
SALIM: Sixty years it’s taken me. (SNORTS) And that’s just to get Salvage 2 in place.
DOCTOR: Sixty years...?!
JESSICA: Alright, I get it. You knew there was an alien satellite hidden in all that space junk and you wanted the technology, hence “Salvage”. (BEAT) Don’t blame you. We’re not so different, Salim.
DOCTOR: Except Salim here isn’t interested in the technology. Are you, Salim? Flip and Jyoti are safely aboard the Mandela. Scavenger is quiet. We have this moment. Speak.
SALIM: If either of you knew your history —
DOCTOR: I have what you might call a working knowledge of it.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 69
SALIM: History is supposed to be what happens to other people. What happened to other people. I don’t know what you call it when it’s personal. When your own life becomes legend.
DOCTOR: Feels strange, doesn’t it?
SALIM: I was royalty.
JESSICA: (SNORTS) Oh, here we go.
SALIM: What, Englishwoman? Have you never heard the story of the Crown Prince Salim and the slave girl Anarkali?
JESSICA: British, not English. So, you’ve a royal ancestor. Not that unusual where I come from.
DOCTOR: Ms Allaway. Please.
SALIM: I am the Crown Prince Salim. I stopped ageing the day she was taken.
JESSICA: (LAUGHS) And people say I’m full of it.
SALIM: I am the Crown Prince. I am four hundred and ninety-six years old — so, Jessica, take my job, I’ve saved up enough for my pension.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 70
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 51. INT. MANDELA — SICK BAY
DOCTOR WHO: (F/X TECHNOLOGICAL, CLEAN ENVIRONMENT BUT WITH HEARTRATE-LIKE MONITORS AND MEDICAL MONITOR BLEEPS. )
JYOTI: (JOLTS AWAKE) Aaaaah!
COMMANDER GABBARD: Not so fast, Jyoti.
JYOTI: Commander! — I’m alive? How am I alive?
COMMANDER GABBARD: You’re in sickbay, aboard the Mandela. You’ve been suffering from oxygen deprivation. Try to relax. You’re safe now.
JYOTI: Safe, right. — How’s Flip?
COMMANDER GABBARD: What’s Flip?
JYOTI: The stowaway, you spoke to her. She’s still out there!
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 71
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 52. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
JESSICA: Four hundred and ninety-six! Stop wasting my time with these fantasies, Salim, and get to the point: what is Scavenger?
SALIM: I am not spinning some idle yarn.
DOCTOR: There I have to disagree. The story of the Crown Prince Salim and the slave girl Anarkali is, I’m afraid, pure fiction.
JESSICA: Hah!
DOCTOR: I know because I once met its author — oh, many, many years ago. A man named Abdul Halim Sharar. (BEAT) Although, now I come to think of him —
SALIM: Was he about my height at all? Of similar build?
DOCTOR: Well, now that you mention it...
SALIM: I was Sharar. But you were not the well-travelled Doctor I once met, in the seventeenth century. He was an entirely different person.
DOCTOR: Yes, I would have been.
JESSICA: I could get the pair of you certified right now. In fact, I think I will.
DOCTOR: Ms Allaway, this is important!
SALIM: People say that my Anarkali was executed for being in love with me. That she “died between two walls”. Men have searched palaces all over this land for those walls; they have claimed to have found them, even. Sometimes, they have changed the ending of the story, to suit their need for romance. But I alone remember the truth.
DOCTOR: So what is the truth, Salim? What really happened?
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 72
SALIM: The story begins in my palace at Lahore, in the year sixteen hundred, shortly after my return from fourteen years in the military... only to find that a flower I had left behind had blossomed in my absence.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 73
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 53. INT. LAHORE PALACE, PUNJAB, 1600 [FLASHBACK]
DOCTOR WHO: (F/X OPULENT. FOUNTAINS. THE END OF A MUJRA-STYLE DANCE, BEAT OUT ON A TABLA-STYLE DRUM. DANCER HAS JINGLING FINGER CYMBALS,
WHICH: CEASE WITH DRUM)
SALIM: (CLAPS) Very good, very good. Now I know I am returned home at last. (HE COUGHS: A DRY COUGH) You. Dancing girl. Fetch water. Quickly now.
ANARKALI: My lord. (SHE MOVES OFF)
SALIM: The rest of you may go. Go!
ANARKALI: (RETURNING WITH WATER) I most humbly offer my lord the water he desires. (FX: POURING WATER) Not that you deserve it. It’s only a [cough. ]
ANARKALTI: What’s that?
SALIM: Probably my Court Priest. Listening to you, Anarkali, and fainting at your cheek.
ANARKALT: (WORRIED) You do not really think so? Salim, my dearest love, we have been so long parted, but we must not be caught now.
SALIM: I can always get a new Court Priest.
ANARKALT: Again!
SALIM: It came from outside the palace. (EXITING) Come. I must see.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 74
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 54. EXT. LAHORE PALACE, PUNJAB, 1600 [FLASHBACK]
DOCTOR WHO: (F/X LOUD, HOT, CROWDED STREETS. AND VERY MODERN LASER BLASTS AT INTERVALS. SCAVENGER — A SATELLITE-SIZED ALIEN WEAPON — IS FIRING ON THE CITY. PEOPLE RUNNING AWAY. )
PANICKED: CROWD [PUNJABI]: Preserve us!
PANICKED: It’s the sun! Come to burn us! Keep away from it! Run!
ANARKALT: The sun has descended! It is cutting the land with its rays!
SALIM: The sun is behind us, this is a new star. A silver star above Lahore. Is it a god? (CALLING) Court Priest! Court Priest!
ANARKALT: There! I see him. He’s running.
SALIM: Then he shows more wisdom than usual.
SALIM: (F/X LASER BLAST CHANGES TO A SHARPER, SMALLER, SCALPEL SOUND. PROBING. )
ANARKALT: The silver beast’s rays, they are changing! I think... I think it’s looking for something.
SALIM: (DISMISSIVE) “Looking”! It has no eyes.
ANARKALT: (ALARMED) The rays, they are coming for us! My lord, look out-!
SALIM: Aaaa-
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 75
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 55. INT. THE SCAVENGER BEAM [FLASHBACK]
SALIM: So.. violent. Yet so peaceful. Yes. If it saves my people. I will help you. (BEAT; COUGHS —)
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 76
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 56. EXT. LAHORE PALACE [FLASHBACK]
ANARKALT: My lord! —
SALIM: (COUGHS) It needs help. That’s all, it just wants our help.
ANARKALT: We must run, we must —
SALIM: (WARNING) Anarkali, no!
SALIM: (F/X THE TORCH-LIKE SEARCHING BEAM STRIKES ANARKALI. IT PUNCHES THE BREATH OUT OF HER. )
ANARKALI: (STRUGGLING TO SPEAK) Help me —
SALIM: Anarkali! Do not agree! You must not [agree! ]
SALIM: (F/X THE SCAVENGER ROARS UP INTO THE SKY, TAKING ANARKALI WITH IT)
SALIM: Anarkali!
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 77
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 57. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL
SALIM: “Scavenger”. After all this time, my enemy has a name. It changes things, for my enemy to have a name.
DOCTOR: This Scavenger... scavenged Anarkali?
SALIM: My Anarkali was taken into the skies above Lahore in the year 1600. Every night since I have worked to bring her back. I have watched the beast circle high above me for one hundred and seventy thousand nights. While Anarkali is gone, I can no longer rule, I can no longer age. Love alone is the reason I still live.
DOCTOR: There might be rather more to it than that.
JESSICA: You think this girl is still alive? Inside Scavenger?
SALIM: Of course she is. “Between two walls”.
DOCTOR: Salim, Scavenger was asleep in orbit for four hundred years until we woke it up. Nothing dormant could sustain an atmosphere that long. Even if her life was extended as long as you say yours was, without oxygen or a proper atmosphere... Anarkali can’t be alive. I’m sorry.
SALIM: Doctor, you’re not listening!
JYOTI: (OVER SPEAKER) Mandela Station calling the Doctor. Are you there, Doctor?
JESSICA: It’s for you.
DOCTOR: (INTO MIC) Jyoti? So good to hear your voice. Put Flip on.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 78
JYOTI: (INTO MIC) That’s it, Doctor. She’s not here. She didn’t come on board with me.
DOCTOR: (OVER SPEAKER) What happened? Did you see her?
JYOTI: (INTO MIC) No. Last thing I saw was Scavenger firing this pink beam. The first ones were this red so bright it seared your eyes. But then it was weedy little pink ones. It can’t have hit her.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 79
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 59. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL [CONTINUOUS ]
SALIM: I’m so sorry, Doctor. It searches with these beams. One of them struck me back in Lahore, I could feel it examining me.
DOCTOR: Yet it didn’t scavenge you?
SALIM: I had a cough... a virus. That’s all I can think of. I wasn’t as fit as Anarkali. The beam switched to her and then she was taken.
DOCTOR: (INTO MIC) Jyoti, are you feeling alright?
JYOTI: (OVER SPEAKER) Doesn’t matter. Doctor, Flip’s gone!
DOCTOR: (INTO MIC) This is important. Are you ill, are you injured in any way?
JYOTI: (OVER SPEAKER) I’m fine. I bruised my arm somewhere. It’s nothing.
DOCTOR: (INTO MIC) Thank you, Jyoti.
JESSICA: Your friend was the healthier of the two, the fitter.
SALIM: So that’s who Scavenger took. It must have been right when they were right on top of the station.
DOCTOR: Let’s see what Scavenger has to say for itself, shall we? (INTO MIC) Scavenger, report status.
SCAVENGER: (OVER SPEAKER) Identification: Scavenger. Visual system failure replaced. Fuel failure replaced. Host failure replaced.
DOCTOR: Host?
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 80
SCAVENGER: (OVER SPEAKER) Confirmed, host acquired. Absorbing. Identification: Phillipa Jackson.
DOCTOR: (ASIDE) Flip. Well, she’s alive at least. (INTO MIC) Scavenger — can you let me talk to her? Can you let me talk to the host?
SCAVENGER: (OVER SPEAKER) Confirmed.
FLIP: (OVER SPEAKER) Doctor? Doctor? Is that you?
DOCTOR: (INTO MIC) Flip! Do you know where you are?
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 81
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 60. INT. SCAVENGER [CONTINUOUS ]
FLIP: (INTO MIC) I’m wedged right in, wherever I am. Really weird. Bit scary. I can’t feel the floor and there’s no ceiling in Sight but I’m rammed in between these... massive walls. Where is this? Doctor-!
DOCTOR: All in good time, Flip.
SALIM: (ASIDE, OVER SPEAKER) Has she seen Anarkali? Ask her if she’s seen Anarkali!
FLIP: (INTO MIC) Is that a movie? Who’s that?
DOCTOR: (OVER SPEAKER) Flip, meet Crown Prince Salim.
JESSICA: (OVER SPEAKER) And Jessica Allaway, I’m in charge.
FLIP: (INTO MIC) Great, hello everyone. If you’re in charge, can you let me out now? Or just ease up the pressure? It’s like I’m pinned in between these two huge walls, you know? ...
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 82
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 61. INT. ISRA — MISSION CONTROL [CONTINUOUS ]
FLIP: (OVER SPEAKER) Getting hard to breathe, jammed in here.
DOCTOR: (INTO MIC) Flip, how much oxygen have you got?
FLIP: (OVER SPEAKER) Hang about... seven minutes. Oh, I got you. I shouldn’t waste it now I’m indoors. (TWISTING) How do I switch it off —
DOCTOR: (INTO MIC) No! Flip, keep your oxygen on. Leave your helmet on and breathe normally.
SCAVENGER: (OVER SPEAKER) Host failing. Repair computers estimate 100 litres of oxygen required.
FLIP: (OVER SPEAKER) What was that? What did it say?
DOCTOR: (INTO MIC) Just... hold on, Flip. Try not to panic. We’1l be back in a moment. Doctor out. (F/X SWITCHES MIC OFF) (TO THE
OTHERS: ) Seven minutes to get her out of there. (BEAT) Or seven minutes to get oxygen to her...
JESSICA: One hundred litres it said she requires. Why one hundred litres?
DOCTOR: Good question, Ms Allaway!
SALIM: We breathe about one hundred litres in an hour but that’s air, not pure oxygen.
DOCTOR: It’s seen or it’s assumed that Flip is oxygen-based and it wants to protect her — but only for one hour. Why one hour?
JESSICA: Better than seven minutes.
DOCTOR: Indeed.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 83
SALIM: Doctor, Spaceguard reports Scavenger is moving.
DOCTOR: It’s on the hunt for oxygen. And I bet I know where it’s going!
JESSICA: Looks like it’s heading for the Mandela.
DOCTOR: Exactly. The Mandela will have vented breathable air when it opened the airlock. Scavenger must’ve been just close enough to detect that. And now it knows it needs it.
SALIM: (INTO MIC) Flip, it’s Salim. Is there anyone else there with you?
FLIP: (OVER SPEAKER) Not Jyoti, I got her into the airlock then everything went... I dunno, pink. Can you get the Doctor back?
SALIM: Doctor, your friend wants to —
JESSICA: Oh no! (CALLING) Security!!!
FLIP: (OVER SPEAKER) Hello? Hello?
SALIM: (INTO MIC) I’m sorry. He seems to have vanished.
SCAVENGER: (OVER SPEAKER) Superior power system detected. Scavenging.
JESSICA: There, on the screen. That’s it! That’s the Doctor’s box!
SALIM: He’s trying to lure it away from the Mandela! And Scavenger’s taking the bait!
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 84
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 62. INT. TARDIS (IN FLIGHT)
SCAVENGER: (OVER SCANNER) High level technology detected. Scavenging.
DOCTOR: It’s all take, take, take with you. Sorry to disappoint you, but I think you’re far enough away from Mandela now.
DOCTOR: Time for a really short hop.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 85
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 63. INT. MANDELA — BRIDGE
DOCTOR WHO: (F/X DOORS SWISH OPEN AS JYOTI ENTERS. THIS IS THE BRIDGE OF A
STATION RATHER THAN A SHIP: THERE’S PLENTY ENOUGH GOING ON BUT IT’S NOT INCREDIBLY BUSY, IT’S MORE AIR-CONDITIONING THAN
BATTLE: STATIONS.
COMPUTER: BLEEPS AND PEOPLE TYPING. THERE’S WORK CHATTER)
VARIOUS CREW: Re-establishing the pizza box area around the station. Thrusters at station-keeping.
VARIOUS CREW: Atmosphere cycling back to pattern.
NASA: relaying Haystack data, no further alarms.
JYOTI: Excuse me, Commander. Can I borrow a screen for a minute?
COMMANDER GABBARD: We're busy, Jyoti. Take that console and stay out of the way.
JYOTI: Thanks.
COMMANDER GABBARD: What in the name of-
DOCTOR: Hello, I’m the Doctor and —
JYOTI: Doctor!
COMMANDER GABBARD: Restrain that person!
DOCTOR: No need, Commander, I won’t be a moment. Jyoti, just the woman. I need oxygen tanks and a couple of space suits.
COMMANDER GABBARD: You can’t just appear on the Bridge of the Nelson Mandela International Space Station [and]
JYOTI: It’s okay, Commander, he’s in my film.
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 86
JESSICA: (OVER SPEAKER) ISRA calling Mandela. The alien Scavenger satellite is back on a collision course with you.
DOCTOR: Already!
COMMANDER GABBARD: The alien what? (TO JYOTI) Is this something to do with your film too?
JYOTI: I’m afraid not.
JESSICA: (OVER SPEAKER) At current speed, Scavenger will be with you in less than two minutes. Commander, I strongly recommend you evacuate.
COMMANDER GABBARD: Why? What is this? What’s going on?
DOCTOR: What’s going on, Commander, is that a robot spacecraft is on its way to the Mandela — and when it gets here, it’s going to suck every last molecule of oxygen from your air supply, before stripping your station of anything useful that catches its mechanical eye.
COMMANDER GABBARD: What?!
DOCTOR: So evacuate, please. Because if the Scavenger doesn’t do as it says — my friend Flip is going to die!
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 87
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 64. INT. SCAVENGER
FLIP: (GASPING INTO MIC) Air’s.. almost gone. I can’t breathe. Doctor, someone — can you hear me? I can’t... breathe! Doctor. Doctor...!
FLIP: END OF PART TWO
DOCTOR WHO: SCAVENGER by William Gallagher (003-NB edit) Page 88

elements.text: PART THREE
(GASPING INTO MIC) Air’s.. almost gone. I can’t breathe. Doctor, someone — can you hear me? I can’t... breathe! Doctor. Doctotr...!
CONTINUES INTO:
SCENE 65. INT. SCAVENGER [CONTINUED]
F/X — HELMET ON FLIP THROUGHOUT
(ANARKALI’S VOICE IS STEADY AND UNAFFECTED BY ANY ENGINE MOVEMENT, BUT ALSO MUFFLED BY FLIP’S HELMET FOR NOW.
IS NO LONGER A REAL PERSON: SHE IS PART OF SCAVENGER;
VOICE COMES FROM ALL AROUND FLIP — AND LATER, WHEN THE HELMET’S OPEN, IT’LL COME FROM WITHIN FLIP’S HEAD. )
(GIVING UP) Help me...
I will help you.
